p: This study advances understanding of the landscape determinants of human cases of a zoonotic disease by considering wide-ranging topographical, host, land use factors and public health constraints. Human cases of Kyasanur Forest Disease tend to be highly localized, with epidemics lasting three to five years in a particular 30-40km 2 area, in which the disease shifts each season to affect a new handful of villages[ 28]. As seen in other tick-borne diseases[ 57], such highly focal patterns in human epidemics results from the interplay of environmental and ecological dynamics underpinning hazard and the human activities that govern exposure across the landscape [ 14, 19].
